pageData.text: Through this introductory organic chemistry experiment designed around the familiar pharmaceutical, aspirin, students gain understanding of functional groups and organic synthesis. Students compare pH measurements of <button className=glossary-text>salicylic acid</button> and acetylsalicylic acid and use iron(III) chloride to test each compound for the presence of a phenol group. They also extract salicylic acid from willow bark and combine the extract with acetic acid to produce acetylsalicylic acid (the <button className=glossary-text>active ingredient</button> in aspirin).

pageData.text: One of the reasons why aspirin works against pain and inflammation is the effect it has on the hormones called prostaglandins. Typically, most hormones are produced by glands that rely on the bloodstream to carry hormones to various parts of the body. Prostaglandins are produced at the location of tissue damage or infection. There are about two dozen distinct types of these hormones, each controlling specific functions from maintaining homeostatic processes to controlling inflammatory responses. For example, two prostaglandins that are particularly prominent when discussing aspirin are thromboxane and prostacyclin. Thromboxane is responsible for the formation of blood clots and constricts blood flow to help prevent blood loss at the site of the injury. Prostacyclin has the opposite effect: it reduces blood clotting and increases blood flow. These opposing responses occur when a prostaglandin binds to specific receptors found on organs throughout the body. The prostaglandin signals to the body through inflammation, fever, and pain that there is an injury and healing needs to begin. Aspirin works to reduce these signals by inhibiting the enzyme that produces prostaglandins, cyclooxygenase, and thus relieves the inflammatory symptoms caused by these hormones.

pageData.text: Plants have been used for medicinal purposes throughout human history to relieve pain, reduce fever, and treat various ailments. The of these early medicines were often extracted from the leaves or bark of the plant by chewing or by steeping them in hot water to create an herbal tea. can be extracted from willow bark, an ancient medicinal remedy for relieving pain and reducing fever. Salicylic acid is a phenol, a class of organic compounds that contain a (–OH) attached to a benzene or larger . Salicylic acid also contains a carboxylic acid group (–COOH) adjacent to the hydroxyl group. See Figure 1.

pageData.text: Iron(III) chloride is used as a qualitative chemical test for compounds with phenol groups. When combined, iron(III) ions and compounds containing phenol groups form colored complexes. If the addition of iron(III) chloride results in a red, blue, green, or purple color change, the test is positive for the presence of a phenol group. Phenolic foods and medicines, including salicylic acid, are sometimes irritating to the digestive system. In 1897, German scientist Felix Hoffmann tried to alter salicylic acid chemically, hoping that an alternative compound would be gentler on the stomach yet would still maintain medicinal value.

Through organic synthesis, Hoffmann changed the hydroxyl group (–OH) on the benzene ring into an acetyl group (–COCH3). By combining salicylic acid with concentrated acetic acid, Hoffmann produced acetylsalicylic acid, the active ingredient in aspirin.

Hoffmann used a synthesis reaction called Fischer esterification,
which is illustrated in Figure 2.

pageData.text: Aspirin slowly decomposes as it absorbs water from the surrounding air. The acetylsalicylic acid hydrolyzes, reverting to <button className=glossary-text>salicylic acid</button> and acetic acid. This is why old bottles of aspirin develop a faint vinegary smell (vinegar is a dilute solution of acetic acid). <button className=glossary-text>Hydrolysis</button> increases the acidity of the aspirin, making it more irritating to the stomach.

According to the Aspirin Foundation, about 35,000 metric tons of aspirin are produced each year—enough to make over 100 billion standard aspirin tablets. However, commercially produced aspirin is not derived from willow trees because that process would be neither environmentally nor financially sustainable. Today, aspirin is one of many pharmaceutical products prepared from petroleum. Multiple organic synthesis reactions are responsible for converting benzene, a natural component of crude oil, into acetylsalicylic acid. Once acetylsalicylic acid is prepared, it is combined with other ingredients to make aspirin tablets. Aspirin tablets are now used to do much more than reduce pain or fever. Aspirin relieves swelling in inflamed tissues such as arthritic or injured joints. It is used in the treatment of patients with heart disease to reduce their risk of heart attack or stroke. Medical researchers are studying how aspirin might reduce complications associated with pregnancy, help prevent colon cancer, and improve blood flow in diabetic individuals.

In this activity, you will perform a qualitative synthesis of aspirin (acetylsalicylic acid) using <button className=glossary-text>salicylic acid</button> extracted from willow bark. You will determine the quality of your synthesized acetylsalicylic acid by comparing its pH and reaction to iron(III) chloride against those of commercial-grade salicylic acid and acetylsalicylic acid samples.

pageData.text: Use the following diagram to identify each well of the well plate. See .

Use the minispoon to obtain solid reagents from the chemical containers.
  1. Place one minispoon full of in well A1.
  2. Place one minispoon full of acetylsalicylic acid in well A2.
  3. Fill well A6 loosely with willow bark.

Obtain liquid reagents from the chemical containers.
  1. Add enough ethanol to cover all of the willow bark in well A6 of the well plate.
  2. Add 15 drops of ethanol to well B1.
  3. Add 15 drops of ethanol to well B2.
  4. Add 10 drops of iron(III) chloride to well B3. (Solid materials may be present in this bottle. Please shake well before use.)
  5. Add 10 drops of 3 M acetic acid to well B4.
Place the well plate on a white sheet of paper so that any color changes will be easy to see.

You have added ethanol to well A6 of the well plate containing willow bark. To extract salicylic acid from the willow bark, allow it to soak in ethanol for at least 30 minutes. While waiting, proceed to pH Determination and the Iron Chloride Test.

pageData.text: Use a permanent marker to label 3 disposable pipets “EtOH” for ethanol, “FeCl3” for iron(III) chloride, and “AA” for acetic acid.
Use the EtOH pipet to transfer 10 drops of ethanol from well B1 to well A1 containing salicylic acid. Use a glass stir rod to mix for 1 minute. Note: The salicylic acid is soluble in ethanol.
Touch the end of the glass stir rod onto a piece of pH paper to test the salicylic acid solution.
Record observations in the Data Table 1. Rinse the stir rod with tap water and set the pH paper aside for disposal.
Use the EtOH pipet to transfer 10 drops of ethanol from well B2 to well A2 containing acetylsalicylic acid.
Use the glass stir rod to mix for 1 minute. Note: Acetylsalicylic acid is not highly soluble in ethanol, but a sufficient amount will dissolve for testing purposes.
Touch the end of the stir rod onto a new piece of pH paper to test the acetylsalicylic acid solution.
Record observations in the Data Table. Rinse the stir rod with tap water and set the pH paper aside for disposal.
Use the FeCl3 pipet to transfer 1 drop of iron(III) chloride solution from well B3 to well A1 containing salicylic acid. Record observations in the Data Table 2.
Use the FeCl3 pipet to transfer 1 drop of iron(III) chloride solution from well B3 to well A2 containing acetylsalicylic acid. Record observations in the Data Table 2.
Ensure that the willow bark has been soaking in ethanol for at least 30 minutes.
Use the EtOH pipet to transfer 10 drops of the willow bark extract from well A6 to well A3.

Place the end of the glass stir rod into the extract in well A3 and then touch it to a new piece of pH paper to test the willow bark extract. Record observations in the Data Table 1. Rinse the stir rod and set pH paper aside for disposal.
Use the FeCl3 pipet to transfer 1 drop of iron(III) chloride solution from well B3 to well A3 containing willow bark extract. Record observations in the Data Table 2.
Use the EtOH pipet to transfer 10 drops of the willow bark extract from well A6 to well A4.
Use the FeCl3 pipet to transfer 1 drop of iron(III) chloride solution from well B3 to well A4 containing willow bark extract.
With the AA pipet, transfer the 3 M acetic acid drop wise from well B4 to well A4. Record observations in the Data Table 2.

Place the end of the glass stir rod into well A4 and then onto a new piece of pH paper to test the reaction product. Record observations in the Data Table 1. Rinse the stir rod and set the pH paper aside for disposal.
